args:
Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" .
Early education programs can’t access federal funding to pay bills
Providers of the national program Head Start, which provides early-childhood education to children from ­low-income families, say that they cannot access the federal funds they need to keep the program running.
After the Trump administration’s executive order to pause some grants and loans disbursed by the federal government, providers couldn’t access the payment management system they use to request funds and get reimbursement. The White House Office of Management and Budget issued guidance Tuesday that the order was not supposed to impact programs such as Head Start, yet access to funding appears to have been frozen.
These funds — which must be spent within two days of when they are requested — are used to pay for everything from staff salary to utility bills, said Donna Davidson, president and CEO of Easter Seals North Georgia, a Head Start provider.
“If this doesn’t correct itself fairly quickly, we’re going to have to close,” Davidson said. “We are hoping that this was an error, but we’re already on Tuesday, payroll is on Friday. We have to be able to draw down that money to make payroll.”
Closing would mean that staffers, many of whom live paycheck to paycheck, would lose their income, and parents who rely on the program would need to figure out alternative child-care arrangements or stay home from work, Davidson said. So far, she said, providers have gotten no guidance from OMB or the federal Head Start agency offices on when access would be reinstated or what to do in the meantime.
